critique: The document establishes a temporary organization (PASO) within the Department of State to support the governments of Afghanistan and Pakistan. It aims to strengthen these governments, enhance their capacity to resist extremists, and maintain a U.S. diplomatic presence. The order does not explicitly address immigration, civil liberties, or economic regulation. It could be argued that supporting stable governments abroad indirectly promotes national security, but it doesn't directly expand executive power or federal authority. The focus on strengthening governments abroad could be seen as a moderate interventionist approach. The document does not directly address social inclusion within the US, so it is neutral on that axis. Ideologically, supporting stable governments and resisting extremists could be seen as a centrist position.
